Ask HN: What to do with old computer books?
description:
I have a meter of old computer books that I no longer need, I can't really see there's much demand for Java 1.3, or Dreamweaver 4.

I have been told that acid based papers can't be recycled, I'd take them to the charity shop but it seems pointless if they'll just throw them out.

Ask HN: Risk of unsafe software in automobiles?
description:
I may buy a car (new or used) soon and am a little worried about all the software in cars these days. Software can control pretty much every aspect of a modern vehicle, and so the idea of bugs in a vehicle's software scares me from a safety perspective. Poor software engineering has been implicated in automobile safety incidents in the past[1].

I'm aware of the NASA/JPL rules for developing safety-critical software[2] but I'm not sure if any car manufacturers follow anything similar.

Does anyone here have any knowledge of the software development practices of any automakers and what they do to ensure safety and reliability? And is there anything else I can do to mitigate this risk (short of buying a very old car, which would have other safety downsides)?

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudden_unintended_acceleration [2] http://spinroot.com/gerard/pdf/P10.pdf

Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34162118

Ask HN: Help recall AI-powered personal assitant showcased recently on HN
description:
There was some thread on HN not that long ago, with a showcase of an AI personal assitant. The case study was, if I recall correct, filling in web forms and searching for apartment rentals fitting specific criteria, which is initiated by a simple text prompt without any additional tweaking.

It was not an assitant in a sense of Alexa or Mycroft, but some kind of an automation. I may be mistaken here, but it may have also come in a form of a browser extension. The showcase demo was most likely either a video or a gif.

Could anyone kindly remind me what exactly the product was and provide a link to the HN discussion?
